message: Happy 2017 everybody! My resolution is to find more time to read. What's your wish for the New Year?

Tomorrow we’ll be voting on the Rules that govern the House of Representatives. I’ll be voting NO. To get Congress back on track, the House needs independent oversight and strong ethics rules. Remember – representatives work for YOU!  http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/house-republicans-gut-their-own-oversight-233111

In our region the kindness of neighbors goes a long way. We have each other’s backs and look out for one another. For a prime example of that check out this story in the Tacoma News Tribune. When seniors on the Key Peninsula have no way to get to a doctor’s appointment or to the grocery store,  volunteer drivers are there to take them and provide company. Thanks to all these great volunteers for everything you do! http://www.thenewstribune.com/news/local/article124016969.html

I voted against the House Rules package yesterday because it weakened Congressional ethics rules, limited the rights of Members to speak out about issues like gun violence, and made it easier to attack our public lands. Today I spoke out against a provision that doesn’t do right by federal workers in our region who keep Olympic National Park running smoothly, take care of veterans at VA facilities, and serve our nation at the Puget Sound Naval Shipyard. Watch to hear why this rule does not honor and respect the work they do.

After intelligence reports from our experts detailed how Russian hackers meddled in this year’s elections, it’s clear an investigation is needed. Today, I joined my colleagues in introducing legislation that would establish a bipartisan, independent commission to figure out how this happened and what we can do to protect ourselves from  future foreign cyber attacks. No state actor like Russia should have the ability to use hacking to interfere in our democratic process.  https://swalwell.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/more-170-members-house-representatives-join-effort-create-independent

New year new episode of my podcast! Check out my conversation with Representative Scott Peters from California. We didn’t let any construction at the Capitol get in the way of a great conversation! And if you haven’t already, subscribe at iTunes for future episodes: http://kilmer.house.gov/news/podcasts

I was honored to join Dr. Charles Horne and former Kitsap County Auditor Walt Washington for the 35th Annual Commemoration Banquet Celebrating the Life of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. sponsored by Blacks in Government. This year's theme was "The Power Behind the Dream -- Celebrating African American Women in Leadership" and we heard inspiring remarks from Erin Jones. Congratulations to all of the honorees!

Tess and I had an awesome time at the Mochi Tsuki Festival. Thanks to the Bainbridge Island Japanese American Community and President Clarence Moriwaki for the mochi, origami lessons, and the amazing Taiko Drumming.

Changing ocean temperatures are threatening fishing jobs that go back generations in our region. A new study from top researchers on the West Coast provides further evidence for why action is needed. The report finds that warming oceans could create more toxins in species like Dungeness crab and clams and lead to longer and longer closures of vital fisheries in Washington state. It’s time for the federal government to encourage innovation and dynamic solutions that will allow us to protect countless jobs along our coast. Read more here: http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/01/10/509008803/warmer-oceans-could-boost-the-toxins-in-your-shellfish-dinner

Appreciated the remarks of President Obama last night. Whether it's building an economy that works better for everyone or rebuilding our democratic institutions to make them more civil, responsive and effective, I think he's right:  "We all have to try harder."  America can accomplish so much when we put our minds to it.   http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-obama-farewell-speech-transcript-20170110-story.html

Over the past few years I’ve worked tirelessly to ensure that the Navy continues to be a good neighbor. Because in our neck of the woods we have the backs of our servicemembers and at the same time are passionate about protecting the unique soundscape and environment of our region. The public should have enough time to understand and respond to the Navy’s proposal to increase the number of training missions taking off from Naval Air Station Whidbey Island. That’s why I’ve asked the Navy to extend the public comment period for the environmental assessment of these flights another 30 days.   http://www.ptleader.com/news/kilmer-asks-for-more-time-for-comments-on-growlers/article_9e41c254-d78f-11e6-90ed-2bc78201d1f3.html

When I served in the state legislature we were able work across the aisle to get things done. There's too much partisanship in our Nation's Capital, and not enough progress is being made to move our country forward. Read more for my take on how we can get this Congress back on track: http://thehill.com/opinion/op-ed/313640-bipartisan-group-key-to-getting-things-done

Today I said thank you to a dedicated public servant and a key member of my team on the House floor. Judith Morris has tirelessly served the Olympic Peninsula and few combine her compassion and guidance with folks that needed help. Her wit, thoughtfulness, and easygoing manner is legendary. And will be missed. I wish her all the best!

Download my latest episode of Quick Questions about Congress with Kilmer! I sat down with Representative Susan Brooks and asked her about Indiana, including people’s feelings on Bobby Knight. We also got a chance to talk about her career as a U.S. Attorney before coming to Congress and why there is more work to be done to help those impacted by the opioid epidemic. You can listen at my website or on iTunes. And if you haven’t already, make sure to subscribe on iTunes!   http://kilmer.house.gov/news/podcasts

Today I voted against a resolution that puts us on a path towards repealing the Affordable Care Act. We should be providing more opportunities for people to get quality, affordable healthcare – not taking care away from folks who need it. This debate is about people. People who have been able to get the treatments they need, or stay on their parents’ insurance, or families wrestling with the impact of the opioid crisis. It’s about every staff member and every patient at facilities like Olympic Medical Center and Hilltop Regional Health Center where the number of uninsured patients walking through the doors has dropped. The law isn’t perfect. We can and should look at constructive ways to reduce health care costs for seniors and families, invest in prevention, increase choices for consumers and streamline regulations. But we cannot move backward. We cannot accept a situation where health care becomes a privilege for the wealthy while millions of Americans get left behind.   http://www.king5.com/ext/news/nation-now/house-considers-first-step-toward-obamacare-repeal/281/nationnow/3ZFQGkGM6IouYC2muWgAOK

It’s important to me that the Navy remains a good neighbor on the Olympic Peninsula. That’s why I wrote to them and asked for a 30 day extension on their comment period on their proposal to increase the number of training mission taking off from Naval Air Station Whidbey Island. I’m glad they listened to that call and extended it for another 30 days. Follow this link to leave a comment of your own.   http://www.whidbeyeis.com/

John Lewis is a civil rights icon who marched and bled and worked for voting rights and equal rights.  On this MLK Day weekend, he should be honored -- not attacked.   https://www.whitehouse.gov/photos-and-video/video/2011/02/16/2010-presidential-medal-freedom-recipient-congressman-john-lewis

This weekend I went to Hilltop in Tacoma to talk to folks who have gotten quality care because of the Affordable Care Act. We should be focused on how to improve our system, not dismantle it and leave folks without coverage.  http://www.thenewstribune.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/matt-driscoll/article126498784.html
Thanks to Pastor Gregory Christopher and the congregation at Shiloh Baptist for inviting me to speak at their Martin Luther King Jr Service.
Hello Tacoma sunrise! MLK Day!

During this troubling and divisive time for our nation, I’m glad that the memory of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is present in our nation’s Capitol building. It’s a reminder that liberty and justice for all do not come easily – it takes work, advocating for our rights, and hope. We should all remember Dr. King’s lessons of forgiveness and love and light in the face of darkness and hatred. One of the most meaningful moments I had as a representative was standing aside the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Alabama – on the 50th anniversary of Bloody Sunday. I will always remember what those marchers did and continue to stand up against attempts to divide or demean Americans. I’ll continue to hope for a truly equal country.

Today I was honored to speak at both of Tacoma's fantastic Martin Luther King Jr. Day events. First at the annual University of Washington Tacoma MLK Breakfast (which you may have seen started with a gorgeous sunrise over Mt. Rainier), and next at the City of Tacoma's annual community celebration. Dr. King's legacy has never been more pertinent to the strife and division we face in our politics.   Harold Moss, the first African American mayor of Tacoma and a participant of the Civil Rights movement in the 1960s, was the City of Tacoma's keynote speaker. Harold is a friend and mentor and we in Tacoma are beyond privileged to have him as a leader and voice of our beloved community.  "One of the great liabilities of history is that all too many people fail to remain awake through great periods of social change. Every society has its protectors of status quo and its fraternities of the indifferent who are notorious for sleeping through revolutions. Today, our very survival depends on our ability to stay awake, to adjust to new ideas, to remain vigilant and to face the challenge of change."  Stay awake, stay active, and keep the faith.

Had the chance to visit a great small business in Tacoma this morning - AST, Automated Systems of Tacoma. AST is at the forefront of life sciences manufacturing, building state-of-the-art pharmaceutical dispersal machines using robotics and high level mechanical and computer engineering. They employ 22 people in Tacoma and are internationally known for their quality product. How cool that they are here in the 6th district! Thanks to Joe Hoff and his team for taking the time to have me out!

Wrapped up a busy day yesterday with Sound Outreach at the Center for Strong Families in Tacoma’s Hilltop neighborhood. An innovative nonprofit serving over 10,000 clients, Sound Outreach is leading the charge on financial empowerment, employment and apprenticeship services, and basic needs services. A big shout out to the clients for sharing their stories and to Jeff Klein and the Sound Outreach team for all they do to empower and support our community

It was great meeting with Poulsbo Mayor Becky Erickson today about the great things happening in her community and discuss how we can help cities like Poulsbo at the federal level. Thanks for being a partner Mayor!

I just left Martha & Mary's in Poulsbo where I met with leadership to hear updates regarding their programs. The work they are doing across the life spectrum from early education to serving our seniors, they're an integral part of our community and I'm grateful for their presence. I also had the opportunity to speak with a group of their residents regarding the issues on their mind, thank you for the conversation!

My last stop today was meeting with Kitsap Mental Health Services to talk about the amazing work they're carrying out. They've seen a 62% increase in patients since the implementation of the Affordable Care Act. We talked about the challenges they face and discussed solutions that I'm excited to pursue. Thanks for the great discussion!

I started my morning at the University of Washington Tacoma with a full room of cyber security experts to chat about my new bill, which gives states and municipalities resources to develop cyber resiliency plans and workforce capabilities. After reports of Russians meddling in our election system and in the face of relentless attacks by other hackers on Americans, businesses, and local governments we need to continue to grow a talented workforce and look at how our systems can better protect us.  Thanks to those who attended and to Chancellor Pagano for offering up his institution for this important conversation.

I was pleased to join local representatives from Pierce and Kitsap Counties at the Tacoma-Pierce Economic Development Board, to discuss the expected conversations that are upcoming in DC regarding our nation's failing infrastructure. It's past time that we made an investment in our public infrastructure. Transportation, water, and sewer systems are important building blocks to a vibrant and growing economy; so too are emerging networks of infrastructure like broadband capacity and smart grids. Thanks to my old boss Bruce Kendall for hosting this conversation today. I was aware as I left the room that the same sign I walked past for 10 years still adorns the wall - "We are competing with everyone, everywhere, everyday, forever."

The US Commerce Secretary’s decision to issue fishery disaster declarations in our neck of the woods is good news for jobs. Fishing is a way of life and central to quality jobs in our region. But the past few years our salmon runs have been hit hard and dropped to alarmingly low levels. The decline has impacted everyone from the worker behind the counter at the bait and tackle shop to the captain running a boat. The declaration will make it easier to get the resources we need to restore our runs and keep our economy moving forward. Read more about it here: http://www.thedailyworld.com/news/commercial-fisheries-disaster-opens-door-to-federal-relief-for-grays-harbor-communities/

Yesterday afternoon I was thrilled to make my annual trip to Lincoln High School to meet and chat with students of Nathan Bowling's. Every time I visit this Tacoma high school I leave with a better sense of why I do this job. These students are engaged, unafraid to ask questions, and represent the absolute best of our nation's future. It helps that they have the best teacher in this state, and in my eyes, the best in the nation. Thanks again to Mr. Bowling and his students for having me, I look forward to returning very soon!

Today I stood up with folks in Port Angeles and Port Townsend as we exercised our First Amendment right to advocate for the rights and dignity of ALL Americans. We sent a clear message that we are ready to stand up and fight for our values. And for the ability of everyone - no matter race, gender, class, or creed - to pursue their dreams. We also stood up today for people. I'm going to continue fighting back against any attempts to take healthcare away from women, or deport someone who has lived here all their life, or take away the Medicare guarantee for seniors, or make our planet less safe for my daughters. Today we made clear that we are going to stand up and fight when we need to.
I had a great meeting with the Port Angeles Downtown Association. Thanks to Young Johnson for the invitation and for all PADA does to support small businesses and a vibrant downtown community.

Visitors to DC might see a friendly face if they visit the Smithsonian American Art Museum later this year. A big congratulations to Stephanie Stebich, who will move from the Tacoma Art Museum to start as director of the Smithsonian American Art Museum on April 3. Join me in wishing her well! https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2017/01/24/smithsonian-american-art-appoints-tacoma-art-museum-director/?utm_term=.13cedcf7dd32

I always enjoy a visit to Keyport, and was honored to be a part of the ribbon cutting ceremony for Barb Hall at the naval base. The new facility is the first to take care of unmanned underwater vehicles and demonstrates our nation is leading the way in helping the Navy carry out its mission  https://www.dvidshub.net/image/3105792/naval-undersea-warfare-center-division-keyport-holds-ribbon-cutting-ceremony-opening-barb-hall

Started the morning off with a great group of people in Ocean Shores at the Answers for All community forum. I was happy to give an update of what I'm working on in Congress, and to take questions from community members with concerns around flood insurance, infrastructure, public lands access, health care, citizen involvement, and the minimum wage. What a great group! I'd like to thank Randy Peck and Susan Conniry for the opportunity, and can't wait to be back!

After leaving Ocean Shores, the City of Hoquiam hosted me for lunch and a Timberworks update at City Hall. This project is moving fast and with determination. I'm happy to have been a part of the solution set that limits flood insurance burdens, offers economic development strategies, and restores critical habitat and public space for both Aberdeen and Hoquiam. Additionally, this process has been a model for municipal partnerships addressing shared problems. I look forward to seeing the success and offering continued support as this effort begins implementation.   https://www.ezview.wa.gov/site/alias__1938/36740/default.aspx

Faith in our democracy and political system is already far too low. Baseless allegations of voter fraud certainly don’t help, especially when the solutions often make it harder for our citizens to exercise their right to vote. That’s why I’ll be calling on President Trump to include in his investigation of voter fraud a study of whether the laws passed to deal with that supposed problem in states like North Carolina had the impact of intimidating voters and decreasing turnout. I am confident that the results of that investigation will confirm that the laws we need are ones that would put teeth back into the Voting Rights Act and counter voter disenfranchisement.  https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.cnn.com/cnn/2017/01/25/politics/trump-calls-for-major-investigation-into-voter-fraud/index.html?client=safari

Recently I sat down with the host of the podcast Beltway Banthas to talk about one of my favorite things. If you couldn’t guess from the name of the show, the lightsaber and Darth Vader art in the photo should give it away – Star Wars! We had a great conversation about our love for the movies and passing the tradition along to our kids. Look for the episode now! https://soundcloud.com/beltway-banthas-podcast/interview-us-congressman-derek-kilmer

I started the morning by visiting Life Proof Boats, a great small business in Bremerton. From design to manufacturing, Life Proof Boats is leading the way in recreational aluminum boats. Thanks to Micah and Bill for showing me around the shop and for employing folks in Kitsap County.

University of Puget Sound President Isiaah Crawford invited me to join a group of his students and faculty to chat about the current climate in our Nation's capital, what I'm working on, and how we spend time in our district here in Washington. What a great turnout! Students were engaged, thoughtful, and energized. Thanks for your participation, can't wait to get back to visit soon!

The news that President Trump is aiming to freeze grants and block staff from communicating to the public at the Environmental Protect Agency impacts the Puget Sound region. EPA investments are important in keeping our environment healthy for jobs. Just ask any fisherman, tribal member, shellfish grower, or forestry worker in my neck of the woods. This week I joined other members on the House Appropriations Committee in asking him to explain himself.  http://www.seattlepi.com/local/politics/article/Democratic-lawmakers-to-Trump-Thaw-out-freeze-in-10887510.php

Today is International Holocaust Remembrance Day, a day to honor and remember the 6 million Jewish people and other innocents who lost their lives during the Holocaust. Families across the world -- including those close to me -- have stories that we must never forget.

We must keep Americans safe and secure, which is why we have a rigorous process for evaluating men, women, and children fleeing violence and seeking asylum in America. President Trump's blanket ban of refugees won't help us protect our homeland and goes against what our country stands for. There have been moments in our history where we have let fear stand in the way of what makes our nation great. Whether it was denying entry to Jews fleeing Nazism in Europe, or the internment of Japanese Americans, these moments are correctly judged as shameful exceptions to our values. This is one of those moments. I do not support having a religious litmus test for entry into our nation and, in the view of many constitutional scholars, such an approach runs afoul of the constitution the president and I both took an oath to uphold.  I also do not support religious registries which is why I have cosponsored a bill that will make it illegal to register Americans by religion. We are going to remain vigilant and strike back against ISIL and other networks that would do us harm. But we must do it in a way that reflects our values and keeps America as a beacon of freedom for the world.   http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/trump-orders-strict-new-refugee-screening-citing-terrorists/

‪I am honored to announce my colleagues have selected me to serve as Vice Ranking Member for Democrats on the House Appropriations Committee. This will give me a bigger role and opportunity to stand up for quality jobs and education, honor our commitment to those who serve, and ensure a secure retirement remains in reach for everyone. You can read more about it here‬  http://www.bainbridgereview.com/news/kilmer-picked-to-fill-leadership-role-on-house-appropriations-committee/

I marched with my colleagues to stand on the steps of the Supreme Court to say that we can keep our nation safe while providing refuge to women and children fleeing violence and persecution to seek a new life in our country. Today I also cosponsored legislation that would stop the Trump Administration from carrying out this misguided executive order.

Puget Sound Naval Shipyard is an anchor for our region that provides quality jobs for both veterans and civilians. Unfortunately, President Trump’s federal hiring freeze will impact workers at our shipyards and facilities that support the mission there. The federal government has a national security responsibility that the freeze will hurt. As workers retire, talented individuals would not have the opportunity to start their career and that could shift assignments at the shipyard, damaging our ability get ships and submarines to the fleet on time. That’s why I joined colleagues in the Senate to introduce a bill to exempt these workers from any hiring freeze. We need to halt this harmful policy before it delays careers for men and women while hurting the readiness of our Navy. http://www.kitsapsun.com/story/news/local/2017/01/31/hiring-halted-psns-looks-exemption-freeze/97252518/

In the small towns and tribal communities scattered along the Peninsula’s coast, fishing is a way of life. Instead of a storefront, young people starting out in this business need a boat and a permit. And neither comes cheap. It’s why we need a new approach for how  we issue disaster declarations when our fisheries are hit by the changing climate and other conditions. Read my op-ed in the Grays Harbor Daily World on why this matters. http://www.thedailyworld.com/opinion/fisheries-disaster-declarations-give-local-communities-access-to-assistance/

Puget Sound Naval Shipyard is an anchor for our region that provides quality jobs for both veterans and civilians. That's why when it looked like President Trump's federal hiring freeze would impact workers at our shipyards and facilities that support the mission there we went to work. I introduced bipartisan, bicameral legislation to exempt workers from any hiring freeze. I'm glad the administration listened to us and realized this would hurt our fleet so followed through with an exemption. I'll continue to make sure workers and their families get support.   http://seapowermagazine.org/stories/20170202-freeze.html

I know there has been a lot of news stories this week and I wanted to make sure that one in particular stayed on your radar. In the past couple of days a majority of Congress followed President Trump’s lead and nullified two key regulations that President Obama approved before leaving office. As someone who spent a decade in economic development I’m focused on making your government work better. But I don’t believe we should do that in a way that benefits special interests or harms the air we breathe and the water we drink. These rules Congress stripped away would have ensured that coal mines used the latest tools to monitor nearby waters for toxic pollutants and allowed the Securities and Exchange Commission to require drilling and mining corporations to disclose any payments to foreign governments. In fact, the rule on foreign governments was originally proposed by former Republican Senator Richard Lugar. In my view this opens the door to more corruption and is damaging to the public. I’m going to continue to stand up against attempts like these and fight to bring people-power back to Congress. http://www.seattletimes.com/business/congressional-republicans-move-to-dismantle-obama-rules/

Black History Month is an opportunity to recognize the contributions that African Americans have made to the history of our nation. Locally that includes leaders like William Owen Bush, one of the first members our state legislature and a founder of the University of Washington, and John Conna, a Civil War veteran, successful businessman, and early settler of Tacoma who encouraged African Americans from around the country to move to the Pacific Northwest. These contributions and countless others are just part of what makes our country great.

Small businesses are the star running backs of our economy — and the work that the Small Business Development Centers (SBDC) play is essential to their success. I’m proud to work closely with the SBDCs in Grays Harbor, Jefferson, and Clallam Counties. In the last decade, the centers in our region met with more than 1300 clients who started nearly 90 businesses creating $34 million in activity for our communities. Thanks to SBDC's Washington state leaders for coming to DC to celebrate this work—and please continue to consider me a partner in the economic development of the Olympic Peninsula.

Back in school we all learned a couple of things. Among them was to treat others the way you want to be treated and that the United States has three coequal branches of government. Lately it seems like President Trump needs a refresher on this basic civics lesson. It’s fine for the President to disagree with a judge’s decision to temporarily blocking his ban on people from seven Muslim-majority countries. But his efforts to publicly shame individual judges undermine our judicial system and run counter to the notion of separation of powers enshrined in the Constitution. We need an independent judiciary that is free to rule impartially on actions taken by Congress and the President. The President should remember this. http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/experts-trump-undermines-judiciary-twitter-attack-judge-robart-n717626

I'm glad the 9th Circuit Court agreed with the lower court decision to block President Trump's immigration ban until a full review can be conducted and I'm proud that Washington state was front and center in this fight. We can keep Americans safe while allowing carefully vetted visitors into our country and providing refuge to women and children who are the victims of terrorism.  http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/trump-loses-travel-ban-appeal/

If the President is going to spend taxpayer dollars to investigate allegations of voter fraud that have been rejected by Democratic and Republican election officials around the country, he should also investigate what whether recent changes to voting laws has suppressed the vote and led to greater disenfranchisement. That’s why I joined my colleagues Elijah Cummings and Terri Sewell this week to lead a letter with 75 other members of Congress to the President demanding a review. Read the letter here. http://kilmer.house.gov/news/press-releases/kilmer-sewell-cummings-and-75-colleagues-call-on-president-trump-to-investigate-voter-suppression-in-presidential-election_

It was great today to stop by Keltech in Tacoma today for a Kilmer at Your Company Visit. Keltech is a woman- and veteran owned small business doing incredible work- for a variety of industries. Deanna and Steve Keller introduced me to many of their employees, some who have been around for more than 20 years. Thank you for being a valued member of our community and thanks for meeting with me and taking me around your facilities.
Thank you to the North Mason Chamber of Commerce for inviting me to speak at your annual gala! It's always great to celebrate your successes with you. Continue to count me as a partner.
This morning's science experiment ... Home made Star Wars gummies!!!  Plan for the rest of the day?  Doing dishes!
It's an important part of my job to hear directly from you. That's why I'm proud to announce a series of town hall meetings. Check out the following details, hope to see you there!

Black History Month is a time to celebrate many achievements—all the way to space! Check out Hidden Figures and follow up by reading about one of NASA’s great scientists, Jeanette Scissum. Learn more here: https://www.nasa.gov/centers/marshall/history/jeanette-a-scissum.html

Congrats to the folks in Quilcene who broke a record for planting 6,500 trees and shrubs at the Tarboo Wildlife Preserve. These efforts will restore salmon and wildlife habitats for generations to come. The Plant-A-Thon has covered more than 2,000 acres since its inception in 2004, helping to protect the forests and waters that make our region so unique. Way to go East Jefferson County! http://www.peninsuladailynews.com/news/plant-a-thon-sets-record-as-volunteers-place-6500-trees-shrubs/

It’s always a special occasion when I get to meet with the National Congress of American Indians in Washington D.C. It gives me a chance to catch up with friends, including many members of tribes from our region. The focus this week was on our trust and treaty obligations to tribal nations. I explained how these aren’t just contracts on paper – this is about people. People who need investments in schoolbooks, help moving villages to higher ground, and access to broadband.  I look forward to continuing to be a partner to tribes.

One of the best parts of my job is talking with students from our local schools about how what happens in our Nation's Capital impacts them, and encouraging them to stay civically engaged. Thanks for stopping by the office, Bellarmine Prep students (and advisor Ken Brown)!

Today I joined Representatives Raul Ruiz and Frank Pallone for a discussion with tribal leaders about how the Affordable Care Act has impacted their communities. In order to fulfill our obligations to our tribal partners it’s clear we need to build and improve on the progress we’ve made with our healthcare system.

Big news for my podcast – we have a theme song! My talented daughter put together a great tune to kick off each episode. Check it out and stay for my conversation with Representative Jared Huffman. We talk about all things water and how we are trying to change this Congress for the better. Don’t forget to subscribe on iTunes! http://kilmer.house.gov/news/podcasts

I’m asking the folks I represent to share their stories with me about how the Affordable Care Act has impacted them. Please write in or tell me in person during my town halls.   http://kilmer.house.gov/contact/your-aca-story

Last year, I had the opportunity to visit the Newseum in Washington DC. There, they have a wall commemorating journalists, photographers, and broadcasters who have died in service to their profession. You can read about some of them here:  http://www.newseum.org/exhibits/online/journalists-memorial/. Journalists play a vital role in holding elected officials accountable, covering war and crises around the world, and bringing information to our lives. They are #NotTheEnemy.

75 years ago today an order was signed that started an awful chapter in American history -- the internment of Japanese Americans. Many of these families began their terrible journey on Bainbridge Island. Working with local leaders a couple of years ago, we were able to pass a bill to properly name a memorial on Bainbridge to remember the stories of those who were forcibly removed. We need to always be vigilant and fight back against prejudice. http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/japanese-american-internment-75-years-ago/

There are people in this world who have a truly transformational impact on their community, and it is undeniable that Melanie Dressel was one of those people. Beyond being the CEO of a major employer that put the word "community" in a community bank, she dedicated so much time to strengthening Tacoma. From her involvement with the Economic Development Board, Tacoma Chamber and Executive Council to her efforts on behalf of the UWT, the United Way, Bellarmine, and the State History Museum, Tacoma is a better, more vibrant place because of Melanie. But beyond dedicating herself to organizations, she also invested in people -- myself included. I will always be grateful for her friendship and mentorship. Tacoma just lost an icon. http://www.thenewstribune.com/news/business/article133944689.html

I started my Tuesday morning off today at the Evergreen State College Tacoma visiting with President Bridges, students, and faculty. The discussion ranged from politics and the economy, to education, immigration, and social justice issues. It's important to have engaged and critical thinkers in our local communities - the program here at Evergreen Tacoma provides flexibility and opportunity for our community and students that travel from all over the region. Thanks to Olga Inglebritson for giving me the opportunity to visit today!

Thanks to the leadership at Bradken Atlas' Tacoma foundry for allowing me to visit for a couple hours  to chat about their business and what's happening in our nation's capital. After visiting with them, I was happy to be able to hold an employee town hall with some of their workers. We’ve seen a lot of uncertainty so far in how the Trump administration’s actions are going to impact our shipyard. Yesterday, I sat down with workers and labor officials to detail my shipyard worker action agenda that I will be introducing soon to show we have their backs. Shipyard employees are essential to our nation’s defense and a big part of our community. That’s why my agenda includes fixes to policies like a lack of overtime for maintenance jobs overseas and the reduction in compensation when men and women have to travel for extended periods of time for their job. We touched on these issues and how I’ve been pressing President Trump to exempt our public shipyards from the hiring freeze. The announcement that 900 helper trainee positions opened this week in Bremerton is a start but we are going to keep at it. Finally, we also talked about my bill that would do away with a rule that doesn’t allow retired servicemembers to take a civilian defense job until 6 months after they retire. After a decade a waiver that lifted this rule recently expired and now we are hearing stories like that of a father and 20-year Navy veteran who can't take a job already offered to him. That’s not right and I’m working to fix that too.

This past week, we saw the release of a proposal in Congress that would effectively dismantle some of the progress made under the Affordable Care Act and lead us in the wrong direction. This plan (known as the American Health Care Act or the AHCA for short) doesn’t pass the test of improving the system. The Congressional Budget Office today determined that the proposal would cause 24 million Americans to go without health insurance and it would raise premiums by 15 percent. It would do real damage to the Medicaid system that provides healthcare to lower-income Americans and their families and has covered cancer treatments for 20,000 people in Washington state alone. It hurts women’s health services that provide critical care, eliminates a key public health fund that invests in immunizations in our state, gives tax breaks to the wealthiest while setting us back in the fight against opioids and hurting seniors. Folks know that I’m willing to work with anyone – regardless of party – to try to make progress. But I’m really struck by how damaging this proposal is. In my view, the focus needs to be on improving our healthcare system. Not going backward. That’s why I’ll continue to speak out against this plan.

Started off my day with the Meals on Wheels crew in Bremerton. After preparing and packing meals, I hopped in the car with a volunteer driver to deliver food to folks. Such a great turnout for today's Student Town Hall at Olympic College in Bremerton. Thank you to the staff and all the students who turned out today. Thanks to Bremerton Bottling Company for sitting down with me for the latest Kilmer at Your Company today. This company has been family owned since 1944. It was great to sit down with you again to discuss business and how I can be a better partner at the federal level.

I’ve always believed that our government, including the President, should work in the public interest. I’m deeply concerned that President Trump has not taken this approach. We know he has financial interests beyond American shores. But we don’t know where all of the President’s money comes from. Saying ‘trust me’ isn’t good enough. He should follow the standard set for all presidents in modern history and release his tax returns. We also need clear disclosure and divesture. I started my day in Aberdeen at Grays Harbor College having an open discussion with students. Being involved in our democratic republic is imperative to moving our nation forward rather than backward; young people and students are important in making that happen. From financial aid reform, to healthcare, to campaign finance reform - our nation's future lies in the hands of our younger generation, and we need engaged and informed young citizens to lead.

I joined the Aberdeen Lions Club for lunch today to give a brief update on what's happening in our nation's capital. I was happy to have a candid conversation with residents in the area, and want to thank Mike O'Connor and Hari Sharma for the opportunity. Service organizations like Lions do great work - building goodwill and helping those without resources make communities like Grays Harbor stronger and more resilient.

This afternoon, I gave a brief update to the Grays Harbor Resilience Coalition partners on our office's work on issues related to coastal resilience and protection from natural hazards. We know that climate change, rising sea levels, and increasing storm severity threaten our coastal communities - and we should work proactively to find solutions that enhance infrastructure and opportunity for these communities. I look forward to continuing to partner in these efforts moving forward!

I ended my day in Grays Harbor at Girard Wood Products in Elma. They're a regional juggernaut in pallet manufacturing and employ 52 people at this facility. I was happy to be able to take some time after touring the facility to talk to their employees and make sure they can put a name with the face. Thanks to Scott and Stan for giving me the opportunity!
Thanks to Gena and the folks at the Bremerton Chamber for inviting me to give an update today on what's going on in the other Washington!

Had a great company visit with Kingston Lumber, a locally family-owned company with more than 60 employees specializing in construction materials. Thanks to Joe Hurtt and the team for the tour and for doing business in our community!

I believe that members of Congress should be accessible and accountable to the folks they represent. It's why I've held student town halls the past two weeks at local colleges and universities. These public conversations continued today at Tacoma Community College. From immigration and healthcare, to the economy and environment, I was happy to listen to folks' thoughts and concerns. Our government is powered by people and it's important we talk to one another and share ideas.

Started the morning bright and early at the Gig Harbor Chamber's Public Affairs Forum. We had a great discussion on everything from Pell Grants to VA reform. Thanks to Mitch Anderson and the Chamber team for inviting me to join today!

I had the pleasure of spending my late morning with Mendy Harlow and her staff at the Salmon Center in Belfair. The Hood Canal Salmon Enhancement Group does regional work on restoration, salmon recovery, and recreation projects. They are active in the community, providing educational services for youth, organic farm produce, and opportunities in the AmeriCorps program. The federal government has been a committed partner to this organization and I plan to continue to advocate for the essential work they do in our community!

I continued my lunch hour in Belfair with the North Mason Rotary Club. I was happy to join this community's Rotary members to give a brief update of what's happening in our nation's capital and to talk about my priorities moving forward. When Congress reconvenes next week to discuss the budget deadline, we should take a cue from Rotary and make sure that our work is "beneficial to all concerned."

It was an honor to join the Kitsap YWCA and over 300 community members to recognize the outstanding women in our community. Thanks to Denise Frey and the YWCA for a wonderful evening - and a hearty congratulations to this year's Women of Achievement recipients!

Thanks to the hundreds of folks who showed up in Tacoma to march for science.  It was inspiring to see people stand up for science, fact, and research to solve our environmental and health challenges.  Lots to do! #marchforscience

I started my day off watching the walls of a new cross-laminated timber (CLT) classroom go up in a matter of hours at Greywolf Elementary in Sequim! Thanks to a great group of community members and CLT advocates for showing up and supporting this innovative and environmentally friendly material. I was honored to sign a panel in the first building of this kind to go up on the Olympic Peninsula!

I dropped by the Tacoma office of New York Life Insurance to chat with leadership and their employees. I was happy to speak to tax reform, healthcare policy, and my favorite time of the week in DC - the Bipartisan Workgroup meeting. New York Life provides investment opportunities and backstop to tragedy and hardship for folks in my district, and for that I'm grateful. Thanks for having me out to spend time with your group!

My next stop was at Tool Gauge in Tacoma, an aerospace manufacturer that employs 130 people in my district - and business is good, they're expanding. They are a critical link in our region's aerospace industry, making metal and plastic components for companies like Boeing. In fact, the piece shown here is a piece of the landing gear of the 777x! Thanks to Debbie Lee for taking the time to show me around, and thanks for doing business in Tacoma!

I love kiddos so I was excited to stop by the Al Davies Boys and Girls Club on the Hilltop in Tacoma. I had a chance to tour the facility, and talk with leadership, but more importantly answer some questions from the best part of this Club - the kids! The Boys and Girls Clubs do fantastic work in our community. It’s a place where kids can go after school and have fun in a safe space. I want to give a special thanks to Miley, our student tour guide who really knows her stuff!
Earlier today I spoke with Ali Velshi on MSNBC about the need to pass a bipartisan budget and avoid a government shutdown.
Great hanging in the Capitol with the students of Life Christian Academy. Thanks for the great questions!

Today, I joined my colleagues with the Sustainable Energy and Environment Coalition to stand in support of the People’s Climate March and issue a call to action to protect our planet. We can’t turn our back on the communities, businesses, and workers that are impacted by a changing climate.

This morning I stopped by Beck Engineering in Gig Harbor where Doug Beck, also a professor at Olympic College, recently was awarded his 23rd Small Business Innovation Research contract. In our region it’s important that working families have access to affordable housing. As a member of the Appropriations Committee I’m going to continue supporting efforts like the Authority’s that are helping folks in need.

Over the weekend a global hacking attack struck businesses, governments, and institutions from South Korea to England. This was the first time we’ve seen ransomware – where hackers lock up personal and sensitive data and ask for money to return it – on such a massive scale. A year ago, I wrote to the FBI and asked them to take steps to ensure American organizations and individuals had the resources they need to defend themselves against ransomware attacks. The United States has to do more to stop hackers from holding data hostage.

Having clean, quality water that is accessible to all families is important for our communities. I enjoyed sitting down with the Silverdale Water District today to learn more about their innovations - like using recycled water - to help keep our community growing in a sustainable way!

Last week I got together with some talented local artists – who happen to still be in school! It was all a part of my annual Congressional Art Competition. Congratulations to Amaya Belden-Reeves for taking first place with her work titled ‘Amidst Reality.’ Can’t wait to welcome her to Washington D.C. to hang it up. Thanks to everyone who showed up and celebrated the submissions of so many great young people.

Apprenticeships and certificates are important to getting students on the path to a good paying job. That's why I enjoy visiting technical schools in our region to see up close the opportunities they offer to learn trades like welding, mechanics, and cooking. Yesterday, I stopped by West Sound Technical Skills Center to meet with students and see how the federal government could be a better partner. Tomorrow the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, Veterans Health Administration, is hosting a Town Hall in Bremerton. My team will also be on site listening for your input on how I can improve your experience with the VA.

It's good news that Former FBI Director Robert Mueller has been selected to serve as special counsel for the federal investigation into how exactly Russia influenced our election. I hope you’ll join me this May in celebrating Asian Pacific American Heritage Month. Every day in our region, these communities make it a more diverse and rewarding place to live. I look forward to continuing to work with our Asian American and Pacific Islander communities to keep building a stronger nation. Together.

As Vice Ranking Member on the Appropriations Committee, I joined my colleagues today to express my serious concern with the President’s approach to the budget. But the President’s budget proposal hurts cops on the beat, families in rural communities that want clean water flowing to their homes, and businesses that need to get their products to market on workable roads. I’ll keep fighting for a better way for the American people.

National Parks have a good problem – they are busier than ever. Thinking  about my interactions with Dawn Lucien as a member of Congress and as a State Legislator, the thing I’ve probably appreciated the most has been the valuable role that she has played. Some people refer to the role she played diplomatically. They would say that she was a convener. I think we should call it what it is. She was fearless about corralling local elected officials, knocking them upside the head, and telling them to get their acts together.   There are very few people in this world who, simply by the potent combination of intelligence, kindness, sweetness, and delicious appetizers, could summon people of all parties, of all degrees of seniority to her home, and make things happen. What has always struck me about Dawn was her amazing ability to get things done. Not only did Dawn convene and simply persuade decision makers – but once she had her audience - she always made a clear case for action. And, the results are indisputable.   Whether it was the UWT campus, the Murray Morgan Bridge, or the development of Tacoma schools and the downtown core…there is no doubt that if it helped move Tacoma forward – Dawn probably put together a meeting to talk about it early on. While Dawn had some pretty amazing titles – Norm Dicks's Office Manager, City Council Member, Delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Calendar – it is amazing what she was able to accomplish with the title of citizen.   She was such a passionate and energetic citizen of Tacoma. I am so grateful to Dawn for her contributions to this community, for her friendship, and for giving me plenty of good marching orders.  Tacoma will miss her terribly.    http://www.thenewstribune.com/news/local/article155577859.html

Student debt has held back folks who might otherwise be starting a business, buying a house, or moving to a new city. We need to ensure that the millions of Americans paying back student loans have all tools available to keep them on the road to a balance of zero. But recently, the Department of Education decided to change requirements for student loans that help ensure borrowers don’t fall behind. These are noncontroversial standards like requiring servicers to present options to borrowers who can only make partial payments, notifying borrowers when payments are sent to the wrong address, or letting a borrower know when loans are transferred between servicers. We should not be doing away with these common sense rules. That’s why I joined my colleagues in sending a letter to the Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos urging her to better protect student borrowers by bringing these consumer protections back.

Today, Americans across the country are marking Juneteenth, the moment nearly three years after the Emancipation Proclamation was issued when the last group of enslaved African-Americans in the United States were freed. Since the end of the Civil War our nation has reckoned with the stains of slavery through terrible stories of discrimination and disenfranchisement, but in the midst of incredible obstacles, African-Americans kept walking down the path to freedom and a better life. Those paths led from Major General Gordon Granger’s arrival in Galveston Texas 152 years ago to courtrooms, boardrooms, battlefields, and the ballot box. Today is a celebration and a reminder that we still have much to do together. For this Juneteenth rediscover a remarkable recording of a former slave recalling learning they were finally free: http://www.npr.org/2015/06/19/415809476/juneteenth-marks-day-slaves-in-texas-were-told-they-were-free

When I was a kid being a pro with technology meant mastering Super Mario Brothers. Now, my daughters can build entire worlds with Minecraft or use apps like Hopscotch to learn the principles of coding. It’s helped them realize that science and technology can be cool.  I want to make sure every child – regardless of their background – has the ability to learn about and develop a passion for subjects like science and math. Part of that is being given the chance to learn about computer science at a young age. But for too long, that hasn’t been the case. Participation in the Advanced Placement computer science exam by female and minority students fell woefully short and is part of the reason we end up seeing less diversity in tech jobs. That’s why it’s GREAT news that last year, the number of female students taking the computer science test skyrocketed by 135 percent and participation by underrepresented minorities jumped 170 percent. We’ve got a lot of work to do to make sure every kid has the opportunity to learn skills that can pave the way for exciting work when they graduate, but we are taking steps in the right direction! https://www.geekwire.com/2017/women-minorities-shatter-records-tens-thousands-take-ap-computer-science-exams/

One of the defining features of our region is Olympic National Park. For me, trips there for hiking and camping have been a family staple since I was a kid. It’s a prime example of how our national parks aren’t just a place for folks to come and take in iconic landscapes. They are also job generators for the surrounding communities and are key to the ever growing outdoor economy. That’s why I’m troubled by a proposal from the Department of Interior to make it more expensive to visit. It’s true that our parks have seen a lot more wear and tear recently. But we shouldn’t put the burden of fixing them on the backs of hikers, bikers, and families bringing a vehicle in for the weekend. Instead, Congress should act on my bipartisan bill, the National Park Service Legacy Act, that would address the big maintenance backlog in a responsible way without raising the price to visit. https://www.seattletimes.com/life/outdoors/70-per-vehicle-to-go-to-a-national-park-big-fee-hike-proposed/  You can also tell the National Park Service your concern about hiking park fees here https://parkplanning.nps.gov/commentForm.cfm?documentID=83652

The Trump Administration and Congressional Republicans are supposed to release full details of their plan to make changes to the tax code. While the full proposal isn’t public yet, I want to highlight my priorities for tax reform that I’ll be pushing for as this proposal makes its way through Congress. Our tax code should be simplified so that folks don’t need to call a specialist to understand what it means. It should also prioritize competitive tax rates for businesses right here, rather than encouraging companies to go abroad. The earned income tax credit and child tax credit should be boosted. I’m also going to be fighting for benefits important to middle-class Washington state families like being able to contribute to 401K accounts and the state and local sales tax deduction. The benefits of tax reform should be fairly balanced so middle class taxpayers see the biggest benefit. I look forward to working with my colleagues so we can vote on a proposal that actually bring relief to working Americans. http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/31/politics/tax-bill-delay-republican-plan/index.html

I voted against the continuing resolution today.  I am disappointed that rather than using these last few weeks to do their jobs and produce a long-term, bipartisan spending plan, the majority of Congress has decided to once again kick the can down the road. I remain committed to working with the members of both parties to pass a long-term, bipartisan spending plan.  Congress has punted from September to early-December, then to mid-December and now to January. No household would run their family finances three weeks at a time. No business would either.  These manufactured crises are certainly no way to run the government either.  That’s why I supported measures like No Budget No Pay, which would mean Congress wouldn’t be paid if the government is shutdown.  In January, Congress should get serious and pass a long-term, bipartisan deal. That’s overdue. Doing so would mean government agencies and the federal workforce has the assurances needed to make long-term plans, which saves taxpayer money, allows the military to maintain readiness, and prevents Americans from having the government services on which they rely held hostage by partisan politics.
